001package io.github.ai4ci.abm.inhost;
002
003import java.io.Serializable;
004import java.util.Optional;
005
006import org.immutables.value.Value;
007
008import io.github.ai4ci.abm.Person;
009import io.github.ai4ci.config.execution.ExecutionConfiguration;
010import io.github.ai4ci.config.inhost.InHostConfiguration;
011import io.github.ai4ci.flow.builders.DefaultPersonInitialiser;
012import io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler;
013
014/**
015 * Interface for in-host models that simulate viral dynamics, immune response,
016 * and disease progression over time within an individual.
017 *
018 * <p>
019 * All implementations must provide:
020 * <ul>
021 * <li>Normalized viral load,</li>
022 * <li>Disease severity,</li>
023 * <li>Immune activity,</li>
024 * <li>Infection status,</li>
025 * <li>A time counter,</li>
026 * <li>A method to update the state given external exposures (virion or
027 * immunization).</li>
028 * </ul>
029 *
030 * <p>
031 * This abstraction enables plug-and-play use of different in-host modeling
032 * approaches:
033 * <ul>
034 * <li><b>Phenomenological:</b> continuous curves with superposition of
035 * exposures,</li>
036 * <li><b>Stochastic difference equations:</b> discrete compartments with
037 * binomial/Poisson transitions,</li>
038 * <li><b>Markov state models:</b> discrete states with probabilistic
039 * progression.</li>
040 * </ul>
041 *
042 * <p>
043 * <u>Biological and Statistical Foundation</u>
044 * </p>
045 *
046 * <p>
047 * The update and aggregation of infection risks across a population rely on two
048 * key probabilistic frameworks:
049 *
050 * <p>
051 * <b>1. Set Coverage Problem</b> When modeling exposure in networks or venues,
052 * the probability that a target cell or individual is infected after \( X \)
053 * random contacts is governed by coverage: \[ \mathbb{P}(\text{covered}) = 1 -
054 * \left(1 - \frac{1}{N}\right)^X \approx 1 - e^{-X/N} \] This determines the
055 * expected fraction of the population or cellular targets exposed after
056 * repeated random sampling.
057 *
058 * @see <a href=
059 *      "https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/32800/probability-distribution-of-coverage-of-a-set-after-x-independently-randomly">Set
060 *      Coverage Problem</a>
061 *
062 *      <p>
063 *      <b>2. Poisson Binomial Distribution</b> In heterogeneous populations,
064 *      the number of individuals transitioning between states (e.g., exposed →
065 *      infectious) follows a Poisson binomial distribution, where each
066 *      individual has a potentially different transition probability \( p_i \).
067 *      The mean and variance are: \[ \mathbb{E}\left[\sum_i x_i\right] = \sum_i
068 *      p_i, \quad \mathrm{Var}\left[\sum_i x_i\right] = \sum_i p_i(1 - p_i) \]
069 *      This is critical for accurately simulating population-level outcomes
070 *      without assuming homogeneity.
071 * @see <a href=
072 *      "https://stats.stackexchange.com/questions/93852/sum-of-bernoulli-variables-with-different-success-probabilities">Poisson
073 *      Binomial Distribution</a>
074 *
075 *      <p>
076 *      This interface ensures that regardless of the internal model, downstream
077 *      components (e.g., transmission, calibration, severity mapping) can
078 *      interact uniformly with the in-host state.
079 *
080 * @param <CFG> the type of in-host configuration used to initialize the model
081 *              state
082 */
083public interface InHostModelState<CFG extends InHostConfiguration>
084                extends Serializable {
085
086        /**
087         * Factory method to create a test instance of the in-host model, useful for
088         * calibration and debugging.
089         *
090         * <p>
091         * Uses {@link DefaultPersonInitialiser} to initialize the model with default
092         * parameters and a given random sampler. The time step is initialized to 0.
093         *
094         * @param config     the in-host configuration specific to the model
095         * @param execConfig the global execution configuration
096         * @param rng        the random sampler
097         * @return a newly initialized in-host model state
098         * @param <CFG> the type of in-host configuration
099         */
100        public static <CFG extends InHostConfiguration> InHostModelState<CFG> test(
101                        CFG config, ExecutionConfiguration execConfig, Sampler rng
102        ) {
103                return (new DefaultPersonInitialiser() {}).initialiseInHostModel(
104                                config, execConfig, Optional.empty(), rng, 0
105                );
106        }
107
108        /**
109         * Returns the level of active immune response, typically normalized to
110         * [0,1].
111         *
112         * <p>
113         * This modulates:
114         * <ul>
115         * <li>Viral clearance rate,</li>
116         * <li>Susceptibility to reinfection,</li>
117         * <li>Disease severity.</li>
118         * </ul>
119         *
120         * <p>
121         * In some models, this is binary (0 or 1); in others, it is continuous and
122         * cumulative.
123         *
124         * @return immune activity level (0 = none, 1 = maximum)
125         */
126        @Value.NonAttribute
127        double getImmuneActivity();
128
129        /**
130         * Returns a normalized severity score, typically in [0,1], representing
131         * clinical outcome.
132         *
133         * <p>
134         * This may be derived from viral load, symptom state, or hospitalization
135         * status. It is used to map infection to observable events (e.g.,
136         * hospitalization) with given probabilities. For example, if \( S \) is
137         * severity and \( r_h \) is the infection-hospitalization rate, then: \[
138         * \mathbb{P}(\text{hospitalized}) = \mathbb{P}(S \gt 1 - r_h) \] ensuring
139         * population-level rates are preserved.
140         *
141         * @return normalized severity (0 = no disease, 1 = fatal)
142         */
143        @Value.NonAttribute
144        double getNormalisedSeverity();
145
146        // CFG getConfig();
147        /**
148         * Returns the normalized viral load, typically scaled relative to a
149         * reference infectiousness threshold.
150         *
151         * <p>
152         * This value is used in transmission models to compute the probability of
153         * infectious contact: \[ p_{\text{transmit}} \propto f(V_{\text{norm}}) \]
154         * where \( V_{\text{norm}} = V / V_{\text{cutoff}} \). The exact functional
155         * form depends on the model.
156         *
157         * @return normalized viral load (unitless, ≥ 0)
158         */
159        @Value.NonAttribute
160        double getNormalisedViralLoad();
161
162        /**
163         * The time step counter for the in-host model, representing the number of
164         * updates since initialization.
165         *
166         * @return the current time step (integer, starting at 0)
167         */
168        int getTime();
169
170        /**
171         * Convenience method to update the in-host state using exposure data from a
172         * {@link Person}.
173         *
174         * <p>
175         * Extracts:
176         * <ul>
177         * <li>Total exposure from contact network,</li>
178         * <li>Immunisation dose from vaccination history.</li>
179         * </ul>
180         *
181         * <p>
182         * Delegates to {@link #update(Sampler, double, double)}.
183         *
184         * @param person  the person whose exposure and immunization history is used
185         * @param sampler the random sampler
186         * @return updated in-host state
187         */
188        default InHostModelState<CFG> update(Person person, Sampler sampler) {
189
190                return this.update(
191                                sampler, person.getCurrentState().getTotalExposure(),
192                                person.getCurrentState().getImmunisationDose()
193                );
194
195//                              person.getOutbreak().getCurrentState().getViralActivityModifier(),
196//                              person.getCurrentState().getImmuneModifier()
197//              );
198
199        }
200
201        /**
202         * Advances the in-host state by one time step, processing new exposures.
203         *
204         * <p>
205         * The update incorporates:
206         * <ul>
207         * <li><b>virionExposure:</b> external infectious dose (relative to
208         * infectious threshold),</li>
209         * <li><b>immunisationDose:</b> vaccine or booster exposure (may prime
210         * immunity),</li>
211         * <li><b>sampler:</b> source of randomness for stochastic transitions.</li>
212         * </ul>
213         *
214         * <p>
215         * The implementation determines how these inputs affect viral load,
216         * immunity, and disease state. All models must ensure state consistency and
217         * biological plausibility (e.g., no negative counts).
218         *
219         * @param sampler          the random number generator for stochastic
220         *                         transitions
221         * @param virionExposure   the magnitude of external viral exposure (≥ 0)
222         * @param immunisationDose the magnitude of immunizing exposure (≥ 0)
223         * @return a new instance of the model advanced by one time step
224         */
225        InHostModelState<CFG> update(
226                        Sampler sampler, double virionExposure, double immunisationDose
227        ); // , double viralActivityModifier, double immuneModifier);
228
229}
